revision.text:
The '''Western Power Corridor''' ('''Westcor''') was a project to construct and supply energy from two [[hydroelectric power]] plants to the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Angola]], [[Namibia]], [[Botswana]] and [[South Africa]]. Originally, the hydro power was to be supplied form the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]'s [[Inga III|INGA III]] project. Later Inga III was supposed to be replaced by [[Angola]]'s [[Cuanza River]] and [[Cunene River]] projects or by the new project in the Democratic Republic of Congo.<ref name=afriquejet> {{cite news | url = http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/westcor-pulls-out-of-inga-iii-power-project-2009081333393.html | title= Westcor pulls out of Inga III power project | agency = [[PanaPress]] | date=2009-08-13 | accessdate=2010-10-23}} </ref><ref name=southerntimes> {{cite news | url = http://www.southerntimesafrica.com/article.php?title=SADC_in_bid_to_revive_Westcor&id=5018 | title= SADC in bid to revive Westcor | newspaper = The Southern Times | first = Felix | last = Njini | date=2010-10-15 | accessdate=2010-10-23}} </ref>
==History== An inter-governmental memorandum on the Westcor was signed on 22 October 2004 in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa, followed by the shareholders' agreement signed by the national electricity companies.<ref name=bopa200106> {{cite news | url = http://www.sardc.net/editorial/sadctoday/view.asp?vol=241&pubno=v8n4&page=BUSINESS | title= Power utilities sign WESTCOR shareholders agreement | agency = SARDC | date=2005-10-04 | accessdate=2010-10-23}} </ref> The pre-feasibility study was completed in 2005.
In 2009, Democratic Republic of the Congo decided to develop the INGA III project by using private investments and the project was redesigned to involve Cuanza River and Cunene River projects in Angola.<ref name=afriquejet/> In 2010 the Democratic Republic of Congo indicated it will propose a new project involving also [[Mozambique]], [[Zambia]], and [[Zimbabwe]].<ref name=southerntimes/>
Ultimately the project was aborted by shareholders when unforeseen changes were proposed to the founding agreements.
==Technical description== The total length of Westcor will be over {{convert|3000|km}} and the capacity will be {{convert|3,500|MW}}. INGA III will be connected with the [[Capanda Power Station]] in Angola via two 400-kilovolt (kV) [[high voltage]] [[alternating current]] (HVAC) lines. INGA III will be also connected with [[Kinshasa]] via another 400 kV HVAC line. From Angola, two multi-terminal [[high-voltage direct current]] systems will run to Namibia, Botswana and South Africa.<ref name=br071207> {{cite news | url = http://www.busrep.co.za/index.php?fSectionId=&fArticleId=4162437 | title= Inga faces hydroelectric growing pains | first1 = Samantha | last1= Enslin | first2= Payne | last2= Durban | newspaper= Business Report & Independent Online | date=2007-12-07 | accessdate=2009-03-17}} </ref> The system will consist of five converter stations: Kuanza in Angola, Auas in Namibia, Goborone in Botswana, and Omega and Pegasus in South Africa. The expected cost of the project is about [[euro|€]] 5 billion.
==Project company== The Westcor company was registered and incorporated in Botswana in 2003.<ref name=mmegi1> {{cite news | url = http://www.mmegi.bw/2005/September/Friday9/2436681301633.html | title= Power to the people | publisher= Mmegi | date=2005-09-09 | accessdate=2009-03-17}} </ref> The shareholders are [[Empresa Nacional de Electricidade de Angola]], [[Botswana Power Corporation]] (BPC), the [[Société nationale d'électricité (SNEL)]] of the DRC, [[Eskom]] of South Africa and [[NamPower]] of Namibia.<ref name=br071207/><ref name=africa110408> {{cite news | url = http://allafrica.com/stories/200804110181.html | title= Africa: White Power, Black Power And Power Shortages | first = Peter | last = Kagwanja | newspaper = Daily Nation | date=2008-04-11 | accessdate=2009-03-17}} </ref> CEO of the company was Pat Naidoo.<ref name=africa2104081> {{cite news | url = http://allafrica.com/stories/200804211885.html | title= Botswana: Govt Still Committed to Inga Project | first= Wanetsha | last = Mosinyi | publisher= Mmegi | date=2008-04-21 | accessdate=2009-03-17}} </ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Angola|Botswana|Energy}} *[http://www.nampower.com.na/docs/westcor.ppt Project presentation at Namibia Power official website] (PPT)

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{multiple issues| {{geographical_imbalance|date=December 2010}} {{Time-context|article|that spans several months, but for many of the lesser events included dates are not given.|date=December 2010}} }} '''The winter of 2010–2011 in Europe''' began with an unusually cold November caused by a cold [[weather cycle]] that started in southern [[Scandinavia]] and subsequently moved south and west over both Belgium and the Netherlands on 25 November and into the west of Scotland and north east England on 26 November. This was due to a low pressure zone in the [[Baltics]], with a high pressure over Greenland on 24 November.<ref name="independent.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/snow-brings-parts-of-britain-to-a-standstill-2144267.html |title=Snow brings parts of Britain to a standstill |work=The Independent |date= 26 November 2010|accessdate=29 November 2010 |location=London}}</ref>
From 22 November 2010, cold conditions arrived in the United Kingdom, as a cold northerly wind developed and snow began to fall in northern and eastern parts, causing disruption. The winter arrived particularly early for the European climate, with temperatures dropping significantly lower than previous lows for the month of November. On 28 November, Wales recorded its lowest-ever November temperature of {{convert|-17.3|C}} in Llysdinam, and Northern Ireland recorded its lowest ever November temperature of {{convert|-9.5|C}} in Lough Rea. The UK [[Met Office]] issued severe-weather warnings for heavy snow for eastern Scotland and the north-east of England.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/11856790|title=The big chill: Your stories of UK snow|date=28 November 2010|work=BBC News|accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref>
From January, temperatures were more normal.
== Meteorological history == The weather phenomenon was caused by a cold [[weather cycle]] that had started in southern [[Scandinavia]] and subsequently moved south and west over both Belgium and the Netherlands on 25 November and into the west of [[Scotland]] and [[North East England]] on 26 November. This was due to a low pressure zone in the [[Baltics]] a high pressure over Greenland on 24 November.<ref name="independent.co.uk"/>
A cold front moved out of [[Siberia]] on 24 November, and cold spell and snow storms also hit the [[Alps]], on 26 November before hitting the UK on 29 November.<ref name="independent.co.uk"/> Other earlier, but unrelated, storms had dusted [[Northumberland]] and [[Scottish Borders Region]] on 23–24 November, before being absorbed into the advancing Scandinavian weather system.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11854881 |title='Beautiful but bitterly cold' weather |publisher=BBC |date= 27 November 2010|accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref> Ireland was first hit on 26 Nov
Heavy snow caused many problems across the UK and the first disruption of Snowfall occurred on 24 November in the Grampians, Eastern Scotland and Cairngorms, where snow showers blown from a northerly wind caused havoc as accumulations up to {{convert|20|cm|in|0}} in Aviemore made conditions difficult and major roads in [[Aberdeen]] had gridlock problems in the rush hour. Further snow disrupted all of Scotland, Southern Wales, Northern Ireland, South West and England and much of the North and East of England as snow accumulated to over {{convert|60|cm}} in rural settlements in Scotland. The snowfall was the earliest widespread snowfall since 1993. Some forecasters have warned of temperatures dropping to {{convert|-20|C|F|0}}. Temperatures in [[Carterhouse]], [[Scottish Borders]], fell to {{convert|-7.8|C|F|0}}, and several inches of snow were recorded in [[Devon]] and [[Cornwall]].
== Timeline ==
=== November to December 2010 === On 22 November, forecasters in the [[Baltic states|Baltic nations]] saw snow storms expected some in parts of Sweden on the next day, especially in the south of the country. Snow flurries were reported by the afternoon.<ref>http://stockholmnews.com/more.aspx?NID=6313</ref> The [[Scandinavia]]n low moved southward bringing snow and frost to both The Netherlands and the north west coast of Germany.
====UK==== {{main|Winter of 2010–2011 in Great Britain and Ireland}} The earliest winter snowfall in the United Kingdom for 17 years was recorded in November 2010.<ref name="news.sky.com">{{cite news |url= http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/UK-On-Snow-Alert-Severe-Weather-Warnings-In-Place-For-Most-Of-UK-With-Heavy-Snow-Forecast/Article/201011415834876?lpos=UK_News_Top_Stories_Header_1&lid=ARTICLE_15834876_UK_On_Snow_Alert%3A_Severe_Weather_Warnings_In_Place_For_Most_Of_UK_With_Heavy_Snow_Forecast |title=UK on Snow Alert: Severe Weather Warnings In Place For Most Of UK With Heavy Snow Forecast | Sky News |work=News.sky.com |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref> A low night temperature of {{convert|-9.1|C|F}} and heavy snow fell over the night of the 25th/26th, which was recorded at [[Redesdale Camp]], Northumberland. A similar quantity of snow fell in [[Aberdeenshire]], {{convert|12|cm|in|abbr=on}} and {{convert|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} in Durham that night.<ref name="independent.co.uk"/> A [[Thomsonfly]] [[Boeing 737-800]] plane with 196 passengers overshot its landing position at [[Newcastle Airport]] due to an icy runway.<ref>{{cite news |title=Plane slides off runway at Newcastle Airport as snow sweeps across UK |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/article-1333255/UK-weather-Snow-affects-Britain.html |work=Daily Mail |accessdate=27 November 2010 |author=David Derbyshire |location=London |date=26 November 2010}}</ref> On 26 November, night-time temperatures plummeted well below {{convert|0|C|F}}, with the Welsh towns of [[Sennybridge]] and [[Trawscoed]] being among the coldest places at {{convert|-10.2|C|F}}. The town of [[Dalwhinnie]] in the [[Scottish Highlands]] saw the temperatures fall to {{convert|-8.2|C|F}} and [[Chesham]] in Buckinghamshire fell to {{convert|-7|C|F|}}, and [[Preston, Lancashire]] recorded {{convert|-5.8|C|F}}. [[Inverness]] recorded a nighttime low of {{convert|-13|C|F}} with a daytime high of {{convert|0|C|F}}.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11871708 |work=BBC News |title=Travel disruption as snow spreads across UK |date=1 December 2010}}</ref> The Met Office then issued severe weather warnings for almost every part of the UK<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The Welsh village of [[Hawarden]] recorded its coldest November temperature since 1944 with a reading of {{convert|-9|C|F}}.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/8171028/UK-snow-freezing-weather-forecast-for-rest-of-week.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Caroline |last=Gammell |title=UK snow: freezing weather forecast for rest of week |date=30 November 2010}}</ref>
The thermometers at [[Llysdinam]], near [[Llandrindod Wells]], [[Powys]], recorded a low of {{convert|-17.3|C|F}}, the coldest temperature for the month of November in the UK since 1985, and the coldest November night in Wales on record.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE6AP1WN20101128|title=Britain's big chill breaks temperature records|agency=Reuters|date=28 November 2010|accessdate=1 December 2010|first=Tim|last=Castle}}</ref> [[Shawbury]], in [[Shropshire]] was hit with {{convert|-12.5|C|F}}; [[Lough Fea]], in [[Northern Ireland]] was left hopping with {{convert|-9.2|C|F}}; and [[Church Fenton]] in North Yorkshire chilled out with a nocturnal low of {{convert|-11.9|C|F}}.<ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/nov/28/cold-weather-snow-winter | location=London |work=The Guardian | first=Peter | last=Walker | title=Coldest November night since 1985 | date=28 November 2010}}</ref>
The severe winter weather resulted in school closures as Northern Scotland, North East England and parts of North and East Yorkshire were blanketed in up to {{convert|6|in|cm|-1|abbr=on}} of snow. Sub-zero overnight temperatures were recorded across the country, with the coldest place being at [[Carterhouse]] in the [[Scottish Borders]] at {{convert|-7.8|C|F}} while [[Benson, Oxfordshire|Benson]] in Oxfordshire fell to {{convert|-7.6|C|F}}. By the middle of 27 November, up to {{convert|1.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow fell in parts of Staffordshire overnight while residents in the [[Black Country]] also woke up to a covering today with warnings of way with blizzards expected in the region with a predicted snowfall of {{convert|8|in|cm|abbr=on}} over the next few days.<ref name="expressandstar.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/news/2010/11/27/snow-hits-west-midlands-2/ |title=Snow hits West Midlands " Express & Star |publisher=Expressandstar.com |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/news/2010/11/27/snow-hits-west-midlands-2/#ixzz16W0rLjOI |title=Snow hits West Midlands " Express & Star |work=Express & Star |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref> Scotland saw the temperature at [[Loch Glascarnoch]] fall to {{convert|-15|C|F}}, a new record low for November in Scotland.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-11856694 |title=Chaos as heavy snow hits Scotland |publisher=BBC |date= 28 November 2010|accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref>
Northern Ireland hit a new low of {{convert|-9.5|C|F}} at Lough Fea, Co Tyrone, and Scotland set a November record at Loch Glascarnoch, with {{convert|-15|C|F}} as snow fell in Scotland, Northern Ireland and North East England.<ref name="bbc11855579">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11855579 |title=Coldest November night on record in parts of UK |publisher=BBC|date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref> [[Topcliffe, North Yorkshire|Topcliffe]] in North Yorkshire saw a temperature of {{convert|-19|C|F}} on 2 December, making it the coldest night recorded in Yorkshire.<ref name="bbc11855579" />
The city of [[Edinburgh]] had {{convert|7|in|cm|order=flip|abbr=on}} of snowfall. As a result of the chaos the city's airport was closed. It was also reported that around 3,000 homes in the [[Tayside]] and [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]] areas were without power.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cole |first=Rob |title=Hundreds of Motorists Left Stranded in Snow |work=[[Sky News]] |date=29 November 2010 |url= http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Snow-Weather-Severe-Weather-Warnings-Arctic-Temperatures-Treacherous-Commuting-Conditions/Article/201011415838366?lpos=UK_News_First_UK_News_Article_Teaser_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15838366_Snow_Weather%3A_Severe_Weather_Warnings_Arctic_Temperatures_Treacherous_Commuting_Conditions |accessdate=3 February 2012}}</ref>
[[The Automobile Association|AA]] said that 29 November 2010 was one of its busiest times in its entire 105-year history as they were called to more than 200,000 broken down drivers across the UK.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
The morning of 30 November saw about {{convert|1|ft|cm|0|order=flip}} of snow hit [[Banburyshire]] and [[Oxfordshire]] with {{convert|2|to|5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} snow falling many more parts of the UK, but much less fall in Scotland and Northern Ireland.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Over 1,000 schools were closed across the Kingdom, mostly in [[Scotland]] and the north of England, with 50 schools in [[Northumberland]], County Durham, and [[Tyne and Wear]] closed.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
The evening of 30 November and the whole of 1 December saw extremely heavy snowfall hit [[Sheffield]], one of the worst affected cities in England. All transport was cancelled throughout the city and the surrounding areas and many people were snowed in their homes. On that day, {{convert|40|-|50|cm|in|abbr=on}} of snow fell on top of a blanket of {{convert|25|-|30|cm|in|abbr=on}} of snow.
The evening of 1 December and the morning of 2 December there was extremely heavy snow in [[Southern England]], especially on the South Coast, {{convert|30|-|40|cm|in|abbr=in}} of snow was recorded throughout East and West [[Sussex]] with the [[South Downs]] receiving close to {{convert|60|cm|in|abbr=on}} of snow.
More heavy snowfall was reported in Southern England on 17/18 December, with parts of Greater London reporting nearly {{convert|20|cm|in|abbr=on}}. Snow even settled in Central London, causing travel disruptions to the city's Underground system and airports.
This was the coldest December recorded in the UK since 1890.
The lowest temperature of the winter so far is {{convert|-21.2|C|F}} recorded at Altnaharra in the Scottish Highlands at 10 am on 2 December.
==== Ireland ==== {{main|Winter of 2010–2011 in Great Britain and Ireland}} [[File:Ireland Aqua 2010 336.jpg|Photograph of snow in Ireland taken by the NASA Aqua satellite on 2 December 2010|thumb]]
Ireland was first hit by the snow on the morning of 27 November 2010. The morning of Saturday, 27 November, saw Ireland freezing in what could be a rather costly cold snap as it emerged that the extreme weather earlier in 2010 had cost a colossal €297m in insurance payouts, due to the snow causing damage was also caused to homes and other buildings all over the country. The [[Irish Insurance Federation]] revealed there were 22,450 claims from the public, the vast majority of which involved snow or ice damage to people's homes.<ref name="herald.ie">{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/national-news/and-its-novembrrr-as-snow-blankets-the-city-2438671.html |title=and it's Novembrrr as snow blankets the city – National News, Frontpage |publisher=Herald.ie |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref> Road conditions in the [[Dublin]] area were made dangerous after freezing temperatures and snow led to icy surfaces and paths were made Icy by frost.<ref name="herald.ie"/> A prolonged freeze disrupted businesses and schools as travel was made hazardous.<ref name="herald.ie"/> The [[Dublin Area Rapid Transit|DART]] and the northern commuter and [[Maynooth]] commuter lines were not running and [[Belfast]] and [[Rosslare Europort|Rosslare]] train services out of [[Dublin]] were also affected. The main runway at Dublin Airport closed due to snow and ice for most of the day.<ref name="herald.ie"/>
The extreme weather was reminiscent of the winter storms of 2009/2010, which were the worst in recent Irish history.<ref name="herald.ie"/> [[Met Éireann]] said the areas worst affected by the overnight snow were eastern parts of [[Leinster]], [[Donegal]] and [[Connacht]] and said the bad weather was expected to last for up to a week, with depths of up to {{convert|10|cm}} in places. Met Éireann put a weather warning in place and more snow for the counties in the east, north and north west. They also put a gale and small craft warning in effect.<ref name="herald.ie"/>
==== Switzerland ==== Heavy snowfall was reported across higher parts of the country on 26 November and in lowland Switzerland on the next day. Heavy snow caused [[Geneva Airport]] to close. The temperatures hovered between {{convert|+5|and|-5|C|F}} for the next 8 days, with 30 November to 1 December having a nighttime temperature of {{convert|-11|°C}}. Similar weather was predicted for the Austrian [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wunderground.com/global/stations/06700.html |title=Geneva, Switzerland Forecast : Weather Underground |publisher=Wunderground.com |date=17 November 2010 |accessdate=29 November 2010}}</ref>
==== France ==== A record {{convert|-15.3|C}} was measured 30 November in [[Orléans]], France. This is the lowest temperature in November at sea level in France.{{clarify|reason=so, does the new record supersede the old one or does the old one still stand?|date=December 2010}}<ref>http://www.euronews.net/2010/11/30/winter-snow-woes-go-on-for-northern-europe/</ref> Ice and snow led to power outages in Orléans.<ref>http://www.france24.com/fr/20101129-verglas-neige-coupures-courant-grosses-difficultes-circulation</ref>
==== Scandinavia ==== [[Trondheim]], Norway's third-biggest city, located in [[Central Norway]], experienced the coldest November since the beginning of recording temperatures in 1788. Especially the last week of November saw temperatures {{convert|12|–|14|C-change|F-change|abbr=out}} below normal.<ref name="Aftenposten">{{Cite news |author= Buan, Vibeke |title= Kuldebølgen fortsetter i sør |url= http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article3927628.ece |work= [[Aftenposten]] |language= Norwegian |date= 30 November 2010 |accessdate= 1 December 2010}}</ref>
Severe blizzards hit southern Sweden and Denmark, affecting flights at [[Copenhagen Airport]]. Over {{convert|30|cm}} of snow fell. [[Helsinki]] and [[Stockholm]] recorded their coldest November nights on record, at {{convert|-20|and|-17|C|F|adj=mid|, respectively}}.
According to [[thelocal.se]] Sweden had its coldest and snowiest start to the winter in 100 years. The east coast of Sweden experienced heavy snowfall in November/December, coming from very cold air influenced by the still open water of the [[Baltic Sea]] and the [[Gulf of Bothnia]].
On 22 December 2010, there were 56 centimeters of snow in [[Helsinki]], Finland. Throughout the winter, the snow had caused a one-minute increase in the average response time of the city's fire and rescue department.<ref> {{cite journal | title = Snow is no excuse for clogged fire lanes | journal = blog.anta.net | date = 22 December 2010 | url = http://blog.anta.net/2010/12/22/snow-is-no-excuse-for-clogged-fire-lanes/ | issn = 1797-1993 | accessdate = 22 December 2010 }} </ref> In Sweden there was severe snowfall near Christmas, especially in Scania on 23 December, on Öland on 24 December, and in South Norrland coast on 26 December. These were very important Christmas travel days, and caused heavy travel disturbances, especially for trains. Worst hit was [[Bornholm]], Denmark on 23 December, which got all roads unpassable for days, which meant that arriving visitors had to celebrate [[Christmas]] in schools or hotels, Bornholm got to 130 cm snow in December 2010, the deepest snow cover on record in Denmark's weather history.
In January, the temperatures in Sweden were warmer than normal, Malmö had 0 °C, Stockholm −3 °C and Luleå -11 °C on average. South Sweden had 0–1 °C above normal, but south Norrland had 2–4 °C above normal.<ref>[http://www.smhi.se/klimatdata/Manadens-vader-och-vatten/Sverige/Manadens-vader-i-Sverige/januari-2011-mildare-vintervader-1.14918?search=yes&month=2&year=2011 Januari 2011 – Mildare vinterväder]</ref> The snow cover mostly remained in all the country during this month.
In February, the temperatures in Sweden were again colder than normal, Malmö had −1 °C, Stockholm −5 °C and Luleå -16 °C on average. South Sweden had 0–2 °C below normal, but north Norrland had 3–5 °C below normal.<ref>[http://www.smhi.se/klimatdata/Manadens-vader-och-vatten/Sverige/februari-2011-vinterkyla-och-storm-1.15400?search=yes&month=3&year=2011 Februari 2011 – Vinterkyla och storm]</ref> There was a storm on 8 February over Skåne and neighbourhood with a sustained wind of up to 30 m/s. The temperature reached −42.6 °C in [[Nikkaluokta]], the coldest in Sweden this winter.
====Estonia==== November started with very high temperatures across Estonia, temperatures rose up to 13 °C, but a week later a cold front crossed Estonia bringing storms with up to 20 cm of snowfall, but it melted very fast. End of November temperatures went down to -27 °C. On 9 and 10 December snowstorm Monika brought severe snowfall and blizzards to Estonia. Little town of Väike- Maarja received in 24 hours up to 40 cm of snow. Six hundred cars with people were trapped on the road in Padaoru, Lääne- Nigula. Many of Tallinn airport's flights were cancelled because of heavy snowfall. Schools were closed. Another snowstorm Scarlett brought a very heavy snowfall on 24 December, again many people were trapped and the roads were closed. Between those 2 storms, lake effect brought more snow, so by the end of the December many places in Estonia had up to 50 to 80 cm of snow. The year-lowest temperature was in Jõgeva -33.4 °C, on 18 February.
==== Germany ==== Germany experienced its coldest December since 1969.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dwd.de/bvbw/appmanager/bvbw/dwdwwwDesktop;jsessionid=36wwNnKcGQPcNF0pvvJ31w6JXdSQrdd5ttq6ypbdv0fx2pQDB5fK!-1682695147!772302560?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=dwdwww_klima_umwelt&_nfls=false |title=Übersicht zur Temperaturverteilung, Niederschlag und Sonnenscheindauer in Deutschland im Dezember 2010 (in German) |publisher=DWD |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> The average temperature was −3.7 °C which was 4.5 °C below the long-term mean. This made December 2010 the fourth-coldest of the last 120 years. Only 1890, 1969 and 1933 were colder. The cold was strongest in the northern half of Germany with deviations from the long-term mean between −5 °C and −6 °C.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bernd-hussing.de/Archivdateien/Klima122010.htm |title=Klima Deutschland Dezember 2010 (in German) |publisher=Bernd Hussing |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> The month was slightly milder in the south, due to two notable periods of thawing and maximum temperatures of up to +15 °C around 8 December and shortly before Christmas.<ref name="DWD12">{{cite web|url=http://www.dwd.de/bvbw/appmanager/bvbw/dwdwwwDesktop?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=dwdwww_menu2_presse&T98029gsbDocumentPath=Content%2FPresse%2FPressemitteilungen%2F2010%2F20101129__DeutschlandwetterimDezember2010__news.html |title=Press release of the DWD (in German) |publisher=DWD |date=30 December 2010 |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref>
Additionally to the cold, about 60% of the German Weather Service's weather stations below 200 metres' elevation saw record snow falls for December.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dwd.de/bvbw/appmanager/bvbw/dwdwwwDesktop?_nfpb=true&_windowLabel=T173200162321273036449357&_urlType=action&_pageLabel=_dwdwww_wetter_warnungen_Thema_des_Tages |title=Thema des Tages – 26.12.2010: Weihnachten weiß und kalt (in German) |publisher=DWD |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> Notably, Aachen, in Germany's west, had 36 cm of snow, breaking the old record of 25 cm. The heavy snowfalls between 22 and 25 December provided for a white Christmas for all of Germany – the first time since 1981.<ref name="DWD12"/> On 26 December, Gera had a snow cover of 70 cm, also a new record. However, these snowfalls and freezing rain caused chaotic conditions for those travelling home for Christmas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,736498,00.html |title=Karambolage auf der A9, Mega-Stau auf der A2 (in German) |work=Der Spiegel |accessdate=14 January 2011}}</ref> Similar conditions had already occurred at the beginning of the month. At Germany's busiest airport in Frankfurt, many flights were cancelled for the second day running on 2 December due to the severe weather conditions. Munich Airport and rail transport were also affected.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11895107 |work=BBC News | title=Lethal cold weather grips northern Europe | date=2 December 2010}}</ref>
====Poland==== Eighteen people died from exposure in Poland{{when|date=December 2010}}, where temperatures dropped as low as {{convert|-26|C}}.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
==== Belgium ==== On 18 December, Belgium had recorded 17 days with snow for the season, an absolute record.<ref>{{Cite news |author= HLN|title= De 17de sneeuwdag van het seizoen |url= http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/2652/Extreem-Weer/article/detail/1197372/2010/12/18/Record-de-17de-sneeuwdag-van-het-seizoen.dhtml |work= [[Het Laatste Nieuws|HLN]] |language= Dutch |date= 18 December 2010 |accessdate= 18 December 2010}}</ref> A church in [[Diepenbeek]] collapsed on 24 December under the weight of the snow.<ref>{{Cite news |author= deredactie|title= Kerk van Diepenbeek is grotendeels ingestort |url= http://www.deredactie.be/cm/vrtnieuws/regio/limburg/101225_Diepenbeek_kerk |language= Dutch |date= 25 December 2010 |accessdate= 25 December 2010}}</ref>
== Record-low temperatures ==
=== Sweden === Many cities in Sweden had their coldest December since the beginning of recording temperatures. The average temperature in [[Gothenburg]] was −6.2 °C. which was 2.5 °C colder than the old record. In Örebro the coldest temperature in December since 1886 with −26.6 °C was measured. The coldest temperature that was notified in December in Sweden was −42.1 °C in [[Nikkaluokta]].<ref>http://svt.se/svt/jsp/Crosslink.jsp?d=52865&a=2284869</ref>
=== Norway === [[Trondheim]], Norway's third-biggest city, experienced the coldest November since the beginning of recording temperatures in 1788. Especially the last week of November saw temperatures {{convert|12|-|14|C-change|F-change|abbr=out}} below normal.<ref name="Aftenposten"/> The average temperature in [[Oslo]] was −1.7 °C in November 2010, the coldest since 1968 which had −2.1 °C.<ref>{{Cite news |author= Kristensen, Jørgen Dahl |title= Kuldekartet viser minus 20,3 |url= http://www.budstikka.no/nyheter/kuldekartet-viser-minus-20-3-1.5849596 |work= [[Budstikka]] |location= Sandvika, Bærum, Norway |language= Norwegian |date= 30 November 2010 |accessdate= 1 December 2010}}</ref> The record low for Norway in November 2010 was measured in [[Karasjok]] in [[Finnmark]], the northernmost county, on 27 November, showing {{convert|-35|C}}.<ref name="Aftenposten"/>
=== Northern Ireland === [[Castlederg]], in western [[Northern Ireland]], recorded a new record-low temperature of {{convert|-18|°C|1}} on 19 December 2010.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-12036233 "Record low temperature recorded in Northern Ireland"]. [[BBC]], 20 December2010. Retrieved 22 December 2010</ref> The previous Northern Ireland record was {{convert|-17.5|°C|1}}.
The same location then beat this record on the morning of 23 December, reaching {{convert|-18.7|°C|2}}.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-12065774. [[BBC]], 23 December2010. Retrieved 23 December 2010</ref>
== Floodings and high temperatures in Balkans == Much different temperatures occurred in the beginning of December in the [[Balkan]]s, where heavy rain caused floodings in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Montenegro, and Serbia.<ref name="bbc3">{{cite news|title=Balkans flooding prompts emergency call|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11909693|work=BBC News|accessdate=7 December 2010|date=3 December 2010}}</ref> The River [[Neretva]] reached its highest level in the past 50 years.<ref name="bbc3"/> The rivers [[Lim (river)|Lim]] and [[Drina]] both caused severe flooding. The River Drina reached a high point of around eleven times its normal level, and the Lim flooded around 250 acres of land, as well as around 50 buildings.<ref name="ndtv">{{cite web|title=Rain fury in Bosnia, Serbia; flood worst in a century|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/rain-fury-in-bosnia-serbia-flood-worst-in-a-century-70739|work=NDTV.com|accessdate=7 December 2010|date=6 December 2010}}</ref> A state of emergency was declared in parts of Albania because of floodings near the cities of Shkodra and Durrës.<ref name="bbc6">{{cite news|title=Nato joins Albania rescue effort after Balkan floods|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11931554|work=BBC News|accessdate=7 December 2010|date=6 December 2010}}</ref> In Bulgaria, temperatures in the end of November and beginning of December went to {{convert|20|°C}}.<ref>{{cite web|title=Strong winds, thunderstorms across Bulgaria|url=http://www.sofiaecho.com/2010/11/23/998232_strong-winds-thunderstorms-across-bulgaria|work=Sofia Echo|accessdate=7 December 2010|date=23 November 2010}}</ref>
In response to the flooding, upwards of 12,000 people were evacuated in Albania from the areas most affected.<ref name="bbc6"/> An estimated 2,600 houses were flooded, while some 7,500 more damaged.<ref name="tele">{{cite news|title=11,000 evacuated from homes in Albanian floods|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/albania/8183157/11000-evacuated-from-homes-in-Albanian-floods.html|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=7 December 2010|date=6 December 2010|location=London}}</ref> Around 1,400 Albanian military and police personnel were deployed to assist in the evacuations.<ref name="tele"/> In addition to domestic resources, [[NATO]] dispatched five helicopters from Greece and Turkey, while Italy delivered 25 tonnes of supplies to the country.<ref name="bbc6"/> According to Albanian interior minister [[Lulzim Basha]], the flooding was the worst "in living memory."<ref>{{cite news|title=Albania 'hit by worst floods in living memory'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11923596|work=BBC News|accessdate=7 December 2010|date=5 December 2010}}</ref> In Montenegro, upwards of a thousand soldiers were deployed in response to the flooding.<ref name="tele"/>

revision.text:
'''Woodchips''' are small to medium sized pieces of wood formed by cutting or chipping larger pieces of [[wood]] such as trees, branches, logging residues, stumps, roots, and wood waste.<ref name=":0"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Energy Solutions|first=Hotel|date=February 2018|title=Biomass - Wood Chips and Wood Pellets - Heating Systems|url=http://cf.cdn.unwto.org/sites/all/files/docpdf/re21biomass-woodchipsandwoodpellets-heatingsystemsfaq.pdf|journal=Intelligent Energy Europe|volume=|pages=3|via=}}</ref>[[File:Woodchip.jpg|thumb|Woodchips]]Woodchips may be used as a [[biomass]] [[solid fuel]] and are raw material for producing [[wood pulp]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/beeh-9ujn3d|title=Wood chips|last=GB|first=Forestry Commission,|date=|website=www.forestry.gov.uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-04}}</ref> They may also be used as an organic [[mulch]] in [[gardening]], [[landscaping]], [[restoration ecology]], bioreactors for [[denitrification]] <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lopez-Ponnada|first=E. V.|last2=Lynn|first2=T. J.|last3=Peterson|first3=M.|last4=Ergas|first4=S. J.|last5=Mihelcic|first5=J. R.|date=2017-05-01|title=Application of denitrifying wood chip bioreactors for management of residential non-point sources of nitrogen|pmc=5410704|journal=Journal of Biological Engineering|volume=11|pages=|via=}}</ref> and as a substrate for [[mushroom cultivation]].<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2001-02-01|title=Influence of substrate wood-chip particle size on shiitake (Lentinula edodes) yield|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0960852400001103|journal=Bioresource Technology|language=en|volume=76|issue=3|pages=229–233|doi=10.1016/S0960-8524(00)00110-3|issn=0960-8524}}</ref>
The process of making woodchips is called wood chipping and is done using a [[Woodchipper|wood chipper]]. The types of woodchips formed following chipping is dependent on the type of wood chipper used and the material from which they are made.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/beeh-9ujn3d|title=Wood chips|last=GB|first=Forestry Commission,|website=www.forestry.gov.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-03-04}}</ref> Woodchip varieties include: forest chips (from forested areas), wood residue chips (from untreated wood residues, recycled wood and off-cuts), sawing residue chips (from sawmill residues), and short rotation forestry chips (from energy crops).<ref name=":3" />
== Raw materials == [[File:Woodchips at Albany Port.JPG|thumb|Woodchips waiting to be loaded at [[Port of Albany|Albany Port]] in [[Western Australia]]]]The raw materials of woodchips can be [[pulpwood]], waste wood, and residual wood from [[agriculture]], [[landscaping]], [[logging]], and [[sawmill]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www2.gov.bc.ca/assets/gov/farming-natural-resources-and-industry/agriculture-and-seafood/agricultural-land-and-environment/strengthening-farming/farm-practices/870218-61_woodwaste.pdf|title=Woodwaste|date=May 2014|website=Government of British Columbia|access-date=February 27, 2018}}</ref> Woodchips can also be produced from remaining forestry materials including [[tree crown]]s, branches, unsaleable materials or undersized trees.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.teagasc.ie/media/website/crops/forestry/advice/Teagasc_wood_energy_guide_edition3.pdf|title=Wood Energy from Farm Forests|last=|first=|date=November 2009|website=Agriculture and Food Development Authority|access-date=February 27, 2018}}</ref>[[File:Bandit_Model_1290H_drum_chipper.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bandit_Model_1290H_drum_chipper.jpg|thumb|Wood chipper]]Forestry operations provide the raw materials needed for woodchip production.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=https://www.teagasc.ie/media/website/crops/forestry/advice/Teagasc_wood_energy_guide_edition3.pdf|title=Wood Energy from Farm Forests|last=|first=|date=November 2009|website=Agriculture and Food Development Authority|access-date=February 27, 2018}}</ref> Almost any tree can be converted into woodchips, however, the type and quality of the wood used to produce woodchips depends largely on the market.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=LAiGEDxN4moC&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=Woodchips+are+a+medium-sized+solid+material+made+by+cutting,+or+chipping,+larger+pieces+of+wood.&source=bl&ots=qdgP233uQg&sig=nGzsaOaQMmv3eIY3deIPkWF7QtE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjInfX2mMfZAhUSbKwKHSYGA74Q6AEIWzAH#v=onepage&q=Woodchips&f=false|title=Bioenergy for Sustainable Development in Africa|last=Janssen|first=Rainer|last2=Rutz|first2=Dominik|date=2011-11-03|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9789400721814|language=en}}</ref> [[Softwood]] species, for instance, tend to be more versatile for use as woodchips than [[hardwood]] species because they are less dense and faster growing.<ref name=":0" />
== Production == A [[woodchipper|wood chipper]] is a machine used for cutting wood into smaller pieces (chips).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dictionary.com/browse/woodchipper|title=the definition of woodchipper|website=Dictionary.com|access-date=2018-02-28}}</ref> There are several types of wood chippers, each having a different use depending on the type of processing the woodchips will undergo.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=NU-NhpbJxFsC&pg=PA78&dq=types+of+wood+chippers&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjdt5vc08fZAhWJc98KHXWVC0UQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=types%20of%20wood%20chippers&f=false|title=Power from Pellets: Technology and Applications|last=Döring|first=Stefan|date=2012-10-19|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9783642199622|language=en}}</ref>
=== Pulp and paper industry === Woodchips used for chemical [[Pulp (paper)|pulp]] must be relatively uniform in size and free of bark. The optimum size varies with the wood species.<ref name="chip">{{cite book |title=Handbook of pulp|volume=1 |editor1-last=Sixta |editor1-first=Herbert |year=2006 |publisher=Wiley-VCH |location=Winheim, Germany |isbn=3-527-30997-7 |pages= 79–88 }}</ref> It is important to avoid damage to the wood fibres as this is important for the pulp properties. For roundwood it is most common to use disk chippers. A typical size of the disk is 2.0 – 3.5 m in diameter, 10 – 25 cm in thickness and weight is up to 30 tons. The disk is fitted with 4 to 16 knives and driven with motors of ½ - 2 MW.<ref name="chip" /> Drum chippers are normally used for wood residuals from saw mills or other wood industry.<ref name="chip" />
=== Methods of conveyance === There are four potential methods to move woodchips: [[pneumatic]], [[conveyor belt]], [[Chute (gravity)|hopper]] with direct chute, and batch system (manual conveyance).<ref name="VTHR Green wood Chip Furnace">[http://www.sredmond.com/vthr_index.htm VTHR Green wood Chip Furnace] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119075105/http://www.sredmond.com/vthr_index.htm |date=2008-01-19 }}{{Unreliable source?|date=February 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.stiltman.com/html/doe_report_part_ii.html BIOMASS ENERGY. State of the Technology, Present Obstacles & Future Potential; Fuel Handling Equipment] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011130440/http://www.stiltman.com/html/doe_report_part_ii.html |date=2008-10-11 }} Report for:United States Department of Energy, Conservation and Renewable Energy, Office of Energy Related Inventions. Larry Dobson, Northern Light Research & Development. June 23, 1993</ref>
== Types of wood chippers ==
=== Disk === A disk wood chipper features a [[flywheel]] made of steel and chopping blades with slotted disks. The blades slice through the wood as the material is fed through the chute. Knives located in the throat of the chipper cuts the wood in the opposite direction. The design is not as energy efficient as other styles but produces consistent shapes and sizes of woodchips.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://greengain.eu/2015/09/23/what-is-going-on-in-the-pool-2/|title=Machines to produce woodchips from biomass of landscape conservation and maintenance work (LCMW) - greenGain.eu|date=2015-09-23|work=greenGain.eu|access-date=2018-04-12|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.woodenergy.ie/woodharvestingequipment/|title=Wood Energy - Wood Harvesting Equipment|website=www.woodenergy.ie|language=en|access-date=2018-04-12}}</ref>
=== Drum === A drum wood chipper has a rotating parallel-sided drum attached to the engine with reinforced steel blades attached in a horizontal direction. Wood is drawn into the chute by gravity and the rotation of the drum where it is broken up by the steel blades. The drum type is noisy and creates large uneven chips but are more energy efficient than the disk type.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" />
=== Screw-type === A screw-type wood chipper contains a conical, screw-shaped blade. The blade rotation is set parallel to the opening so wood is pulled into the chipper by the spiral motion. Screw-type, also called high-torque rollers, are popular for residential use due to being quiet, easy to use and safer than disk and drum types.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.landpoweruk.com/content/28-wood-chipper-wood-shredder-guide-landpower-uk|title=Wood Chipper & Wood Shredder Guide {{!}} Landpower UK {{!}} Landpower Machinery - Templecombe, Somerset, Dorset, Hampshire, Wiltshire & Devon|website=www.landpoweruk.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-12}}</ref>
== Applications ==
Woodchips are used primarily as a raw material for technical wood processing. In industry, processing of bark chips is often separated after peeling the logs due to different chemical properties.
=== Wood pulp === {{Main|Wood pulp}} Only the heartwood and sapwood are useful for making pulp. Bark contains relatively few useful fibres and is removed and used as fuel to provide steam for use in the [[pulp mill]]. Most pulping processes require that the wood be chipped and screened to provide uniform sized chips.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ramgopal|first=Y. N.|date=June 2016|title=A Study on Production of Pulp from Ground Nut Shells|url=https://www.ijser.org/researchpaper/A-Study-on-Production-of-Pulp-from-Ground-Nut-Shells.pdf|journal=International Journal of Scientific and Engineering Research|volume=7|pages=423–428|via=IJSER}}</ref>
=== Mulch === Woodchips are also used as landscape and garden [[mulch]], producing benefits such as [[water conservation]], weed control, reducing and preventing [[soil erosion]], and for supporting germination of native seeds and [[acorn]]s in [[Restoration ecology|habitat restoration]] projects. As the [[ramial chipped wood]] decomposes it improves the soil structure, permeability, bioactivity, and nutrient availability of the soil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/cpp/Revegetation.pdf|title=Natural Regeneration|date=October 2012|website=Office of Environment and Heritage, Department of Premier and Cabinet NSW|access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref> Woodchips when used as a [[mulch]] are at least three inches thick.
=== Playground surfacing === Woodchips can be reprocessed into an extremely effective playground surfacing material, or impact-attenuation surface.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncemch.org/child-care-health-consultants/Part2/2-4_playground_surfacing.pdf|title=Playground Surfacing Materials ADA-Approved and Non-Appproved|last=Marshall|first=Mike|date=March 25, 2011|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171214150446/https://www.ncemch.org/child-care-health-consultants/Part2/2-4_playground_surfacing.pdf|archive-date=2017-12-14|dead-url=no|access-date=July 25, 2017|df=}}</ref> When used as [[playground surfacing]] (soft fall, cushion fall, or play chip, as it is sometimes known), woodchips can be very effective in lessening the impact of falls from playground equipment. When spread to depths of one foot (30 centimetres) playground woodchips can be effective at reducing impacts in falls up to 11 feet (3 meters). Playground woodchips are also an environmentally friendly alternative to rubber type playground surfaces.<ref name=":2" />
=== Barbecuing === Woodchips can also be used to infuse flavor and enhance the smoky taste to barbecued meats and vegetables. Several different species of wood can be used depending on the type of flavor wanted. For a mild, sweet fruity flavor, apple wood can be used while hickory gives a smoky, bacon-like flavor. Other different types of wood used are cherry, hickory, mesquite and pecan.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Use Smoking Woods|url=https://www.weber.com/US/en/blog/smoking-woods-strike-while-the-grill-is-hot|accessdate=12 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Bioreactor === Woodchip piles at the edge of a field can inhibit nitrates from running off into water tiles. They are a simple measure for farmers to reduce nitrate pollution of the watershed without them having to change their land management practice. A 2011 study showed that most of the nitrate removal was due to [[heterotrophic]] denitrification.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=21696799|year=2011|author1=Warneke|first1=S|title=A comparison of different approaches for measuring denitrification rates in a nitrate removing bioreactor|journal=Water Research|volume=45|issue=14|pages=4141–51|last2=Schipper|first2=L. A.|last3=Bruesewitz|first3=D. A.|last4=Baisden|first4=W. T.|doi=10.1016/j.watres.2011.05.027}}</ref> A 2013 experiment from Ireland showed that after 70 days of startup, a woodchip pile loaded with liquid pig manure at 5 L/m<sup>2</sup>/day removed an average of 90% of nitrate in the form of [[ammonium]] after one month.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=23837316|year=2013|author1=Carney|first1=K. N.|title=Treatment of separated piggery anaerobic digestate liquid using woodchip biofilters|journal=Environmental Technology|volume=34|issue=5–8|pages=663–70|last2=Rodgers|first2=M|last3=Lawlor|first3=P. G.|last4=Zhan|first4=X|doi=10.1080/09593330.2012.710408}}</ref> A January 2015 study from Ohio State University showed very low [[nitrogen]] gas, i.e. [[greenhouse gas emissions]] from nitrate transformation under the anaerobic conditions of the woodchip bioreactor. Scientists constructed a model for water flow and nitrate removal kinetics which can be used to design [[denitrification]] beds.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=25638338|year=2015|author1=Ghane|first1=E|title=Modeling nitrate removal in a denitrification bed|journal=Water Research|volume=71|pages=294–305|last2=Fausey|first2=N. R.|last3=Brown|first3=L. C.|doi=10.1016/j.watres.2014.10.039}}</ref> It is unknown if other nutrients like [[phosphorus]] or pathogens are affected by the bioreactor as well.
=== Fuel === Woodchips have been traditionally used as solid fuel for [[space heating]] or in energy plants to generate [[electric power]] from [[renewable energy]]. The main source of forest chips in Europe and in most of the countries{{which|date=March 2015}} have been logging residues. It is expected that the shares of stumps and roundwood will increase in the future.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.createwood.com/products/wooden-chips/|title=Wooden Chips|date=2018|website=A&S Enterprises|access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref> {{As of| 2013}} in the EU, the estimates for biomass potential for energy, available under current 2018 conditions including sustainable use of the forest as well as providing wood to the traditional forest sectors, are: 277 million m<sup>3</sup>, for above ground biomass and 585 million m<sup>3</sup> for total biomass.<ref name="Yanez et al 2013">{{cite journal | title = Forest chips for energy in Europe: current procurement methods and potentials | journal = Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews | volume =21 | issue = | pages =562–571 | year =2013 | doi = 10.1016/j.rser.2012.12.016 | author =Díaz-Yáñez O, Mola-Yudego, B; Anttila P, Röser D, Asikainen A.}}</ref>
The newer fuel systems for heating use either woodchips or [[wood pellets]]. The advantage of woodchips is cost, the advantage of wood pellets is the controlled fuel value. The use of woodchips in automated heating systems, is based on a robust technology.<ref name=":4" />
The size of the woodchips is particularly important when burning woodchip in small plants. Unfortunately there are not many standards to decide the fractions of woodchip. One standard is the GF60 which is commonly used in smaller plants, including small industries, villas, and apartment buildings. "GF60" is known as "Fine, dry, small chips". The requirements for GF60 are that the moisture is between 10–30% and the fractions of the woodchips are distributed as follows: 0–3.5mm: <8%, 3.5–30mm: <7%, 30–60 mm: 80–100%, 60–100 mm: <3%, 100–120 mm: <2%.<ref name=":4" />
The energy content in one cubic metre is normally higher than in one cubic metre wood logs, but can vary greatly depending on moisture. The moisture is decided by the handling of the raw material. If the trees are taken down in the winter and left to dry for the summer (with teas in the bark and covered so rain can't reach to them), and is then chipped in the fall, the woodchips' moisture content will be approximately 20–25%. The energy content, then, is approximately 3.5–4.5kWh/kg (~150–250 kg/cubic metre).<ref name=":4" />
[[Coal power plant]]s have been converted to run on woodchips, which is fairly straightforward to do, since they both use an identical [[steam turbine]] [[heat engine]], and the cost of woodchip fuel is comparable to [[coal]].<ref name=":4" />
Solid [[biomass]] is an attractive fuel for addressing the concerns of the [[energy crisis]] and [[climate change]], since the fuel is affordable, widely available, close to [[carbon neutral]] and thus climate-neutral in terms of carbon dioxide (CO2), since in the ideal case only the carbon dioxide which was drawn in during the tree’s growth and stored in the wood is released into the atmosphere again.<ref name=":4" />
==== Waste and emissions ==== Compared to the solid waste disposal problems of coal and nuclear fuels, woodchip fuel's waste disposal problems are less grave; in a study from 2001 [[fly ash]] from woodchip combustion had 28.6 mg cadmium/kg dry matter. Compared to fly ash from burning of straw, cadmium was bound more heavily, with only small amounts of cadmium leached. It was speciated as a form of [[cadmium oxide]], cadmium silicate (CdSiO<sub>3</sub>); authors noted that adding it to agricultural or forest soils in the long-term could cause a problem with accumulation of cadmium.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=11572586|year=2001|author1=Hansen|first1=H. K.|title=Speciation and mobility of cadmium in straw and wood combustion fly ash|journal=Chemosphere|volume=45|issue=1|pages=123–8|last2=Pedersen|first2=A. J.|last3=Ottosen|first3=L. M.|last4=Villumsen|first4=A|doi=10.1016/s0045-6535(01)00026-1}}</ref>
Like coal, wood combustion is a known source of [[mercury (element)|mercury]] emissions, particularly in northern climates during winter. The mercury is both gaseous as elemental mercury (especially when wood pellets are burned) or mercury oxide, and solid PM2.5 particulate matter when untreated wood is used.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=21620435|year=2011|author1=Huang|first1=J|title=Mercury (Hg) emissions from domestic biomass combustion for space heating|journal=Chemosphere|volume=84|issue=11|pages=1694–9|last2=Hopke|first2=P. K.|last3=Choi|first3=H. D.|last4=Laing|first4=J. R.|last5=Cui|first5=H|last6=Zananski|first6=T. J.|last7=Chandrasekaran|first7=S. R.|last8=Rattigan|first8=O. V.|last9=Holsen|first9=T. M.|doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2011.04.078}}</ref>
When wood burning is used for space heating, indoor emissions of [[1,3-butadiene]], [[benzene]], [[formaldehyde]] and [[acetaldehyde]], which are suspected or known carcinogenic compounds, are elevated. The cancer risk from these after exposure to wood smoke is estimated to be low in developed countries.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid= 1721393|pmc= 2965621|year= 1991|author1= Rilo|first1= H. L.|title= Effect of FK 506 on function of human islets of Langerhans|journal= Transplantation proceedings|volume= 23|issue= 6|pages= 3164–5|last2= Zeng|first2= Y|last3= Alejandro|first3= R|last4= Carroll|first4= P. B.|last5= Bereiter|first5= D|last6= Venkataramanan|first6= R|last7= Tzakis|first7= A. G.|last8= Starzl|first8= T. E.|last9= Ricordi|first9= C}}</ref>
Certain techniques for burning woodchips result in the production of [[biochar]] – effectively charcoal – which can be either utilised as charcoal, or returned to the soil, since [[wood ash]] can be used as a mineral-rich plant [[fertilizer]]. The latter method can result in an effectively carbon-negative system, as well as acting as a very effective soil conditioner, enhancing water and nutrient retention in poor soils.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chalker-Scott|first=Linda|date=December 2007|title=Impact of Mulches on Landscape Plants and the Environment - A Review|url=http://extension.oregonstate.edu/lane/sites/default/files/documents/soileffectsofmulching.pdf|journal=Journal of Environmental Horticulture|volume=25|pages=239–249|via=Oregon State}}</ref>
==== Automated handling of solid fuel ==== Unlike the smooth, uniform shape of manufactured [[wood pellets]], woodchip sizes vary and are often mixed with twigs and sawdust. This mixture has a higher probability of jamming in small feed mechanisms. Thus, sooner or later, one or more jams is likely to occur. This reduces the reliability of the system, as well as increasing maintenance costs. Despite what some pellet stove manufacturers may say, researchers who are experienced with woodchips, say they are not compatible with the 2 inch (5 cm) auger used in pellet stoves.<ref name="VTHR Green wood Chip Furnace" />
==== Micro combined heat and power ==== {{Main|Micro combined heat and power}} Wood is occasionally used to power engines, such as [[steam engines]], [[Stirling engines]], and [[Otto engines]] running on [[woodgas]]. As of 2008, these systems are rare, but as technology and the need for it develops, it is likely to be more common in the future. For the time being, wood can be increasingly used for heating applications. This will reduce the demand for heating oil, and thereby allow a greater percentage of fuel oil to be used for applications such as [[internal combustion engines]], which are less compatible with wood based fuel and other solid biomass fuels. Heating applications generally do not require refined or processed fuels, which are almost always more expensive.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=December 2010|title=Biomass|url=https://corporate.vattenfall.com/globalassets/corporate/about_vattenfall/research_and_development/r-d_magazine_december_2010.pdf|journal=Vattenfall Research and Development Magazine|volume=4|pages=1–20|via=Vattenfall Corporate}}</ref>
==== Comparison to other fuels ==== Woodchips are similar to [[wood pellets]], in that the movement and handling is more amenable to automation than cord wood, particularly for smaller systems. Woodchips are less expensive to produce than wood pellets, which must be processed in specialized facilities. While avoiding the costs associated with refinement, the lower [[density]] and higher moisture content of woodchips reduces their [[calorific value]], substantially increasing the feedstock needed to generate an equivalent amount of heat. Greater physical volume requirements also increase the expense and emissions impact of trucking, storing and/or shipping the wood.
Woodchips are less expensive than [[cord wood]], because the harvesting is faster and more highly automated. Woodchips are of greater supply, partly because all parts of a tree can be chipped, whereas small limbs and branches can require substantial labor to convert to cord wood. Cord wood generally needs to be "seasoned" or "dry" before it can be burned cleanly and efficiently. On the other hand, woodchip systems are typically designed to cleanly and efficiently burn "green chips" with very high moisture content of 43–47% (wet basis).<ref name="VTHR Green wood Chip Furnace" /> (see [[gasification]] and [[woodgas]])
== Environmental aspects == Compared to conventional timber harvesting, woodchip harvesting has a greater impact on the environment, since a larger proportion of biomass is removed.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=http://www.videncenter.dk/Groenne%20trae%20haefte/Groen_Engelsk/Kap_05.pdf|title=Environmental Issues During the Production and Handling of Wood Fuels|date=March 2004|website=Videncenter|access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref> Increased use of woodchips can have negative effects on the stability and long-term growth of the forests in which they're removed from. For instance, chipping of trees from forests has been shown to increase the removal of plant nutrients and organic matter from an ecosystem, thereby reducing both the nutrients and humus content of the soil.<ref name=":22" /> One option to balance the negative effects of woodchip harvesting is to return the woodchip ash to the forest which would restore some of the lost nutrients back into the soil.<ref name=":22" />
If woodchips are harvested as a by-product of [[sustainable]] forestry practices, then this is considered a source of [[renewable energy]].<ref>{{Cite journal|date=November 1999|title=Large Scale Power Generation Using Forestry and Wood Industry By Products|url=http://www.ieaghg.org/docs/General_Docs/Reports/PH3_11%20-%20Wood%20industry%20wastes%20for%20power%20gen.pdf|journal=IEA Greenhouse Gas R&D Programme|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> On the other hand, harvesting practices, such as [[clear cutting|clearcutting]] large areas, are highly damaging to forest [[ecosystem]]s.
Theoretically, whole-tree chip harvesting does not have as high a [[solar energy]] efficiency compared to [[short rotation coppice]]; however, it can be an energy-efficient and low-cost method of harvesting.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dou|first=Chang|last2=Marcondes|first2=Wilian F.|last3=Djaja|first3=Jessica E.|last4=Bura|first4=Renata|last5=Gustafson|first5=Rick|date=2017-06-05|title=Can we use short rotation coppice poplar for sugar based biorefinery feedstock? Bioconversion of 2-year-old poplar grown as short rotation coppice|journal=Biotechnology for Biofuels|volume=10|doi=10.1186/s13068-017-0829-6|pmc=5460468|pmid=28592993}}</ref> In some cases, this practice may be controversial when whole-tree harvesting may often be associated with clear cutting and perhaps other questionable forestry practices.
=== Waste processing === Woodchips and bark chips can be used as bulking agents in [[industrial composting]] of municipal [[biodegradeable]] waste, particularly [[biosolids]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Malinska|first=Krystyna|last2=Zabochnick|first2=A-Swiatek|date=2013|title=SELECTION OF BULKING AGENTS FOR COMPOSTING OF SEWAGE SLUDGE|url=http://epe.pwr.wroc.pl/2013/2-2013/Malinska_2-2013.pdf|journal=Environment Protection Engineering|volume=39|pages=91–103|via=}}</ref> Woodchip biomass does not have the waste disposal issues of coal and nuclear power, since wood ash can be used directly as a mineral-rich plant fertilizer.
=== Forest fire prevention === Woodchip harvesting can be used in concert with creating man made [[firebreak]]s, which are used as barriers to the spread of [[wildfire]]. Undergrowth coppice is ideal for chipping, and larger trees may be left in place to shade the forest floor and reduce the rate of fuel accumulation.
== Market products, supply and demand == Currently, domestic or residential sized systems are not available in products for sale on the general market. Homemade devices have been produced, that are small-scale, clean-burning, and efficient for woodchip fuels. Much of the research activity to date, has consisted of small budget projects that are self-funded. The majority of funding for energy research has been for liquid [[biofuels]].
=== United States === Woodchip costs usually depend on such factors as the distance from the point of delivery, the type of material (such as bark, sawmill residue or whole-tree chips), demand by other markets and how the wood fuel is transported. Chips delivered directly to the (powerplant) station by truck are less expensive than those delivered ... and shipped by railcar. The range of prices is typically between US$18 to US$30 per (wet)-ton delivered.<ref>[http://www.burlingtonelectric.com/specialtopics/mcneil.htm Woodchip price factors for a power Generating Station in Burlington, VT, US] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410180748/http://www.burlingtonelectric.com/SpecialTopics/Mcneil.htm |date=2008-04-10 }}</ref>
In 2006, prices were US$15 and US$30 per wet-ton in the northeast.<ref>[http://www.sredmond.com/vthr_index.htm Vermont Heat Research – An Experimental Wood Chip Furnace] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119075105/http://www.sredmond.com/vthr_index.htm |date=2008-01-19 }}</ref>
In the 20 years leading up to 2008, prices have fluctuated between US$60–70/oven-dry metric ton (odmt) in the southern states, and between US$60/odmt and US$160/odmt in the Northwest.<ref>[http://forestnewswire.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=118:first-quarter-wood-chip-costs-up-almost-50-in-western-us-but-pulpmills-in-the-us-south-experienced-only-small-upward-price-adjustments&catid=1:latest First quarter wood chip costs up almost 50% in western US, but pulpmills in the US South experienced only small upward price adjustments] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120211174013/http://forestnewswire.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=118:first-quarter-wood-chip-costs-up-almost-50-in-western-us-but-pulpmills-in-the-us-south-experienced-only-small-upward-price-adjustments&catid=1:latest |date=2012-02-11 }}</ref>
=== Canada === Wood chips have been used as a source of single-dwelling heating in Canada since the early days of settling but the development of oil and natural gas has dramatically decreased its usage. Most of the wood chip usage is by installations such as schools, hospitals and prisons. Prince Edward Island (PEI) has the most wood-chip plants due to high electricity rates and subsidies from the federal government. Nova Scotia has a 2.5 MW wood chip burning system that provides power to a textile factory as well as systems that provide power to a poultry processing plant, two hospitals and an agricultural college.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Consulting Services|first=Flann|date=April 2018|title=Woodchip Combustion in Eastern Canada|url=https://www.reap-canada.com/online_library/agri_fibres_forestry/29%20Woodchip%20Combustion.pdf|journal=R.E.A.P. Canada|volume=|pages=1–33|via=}}</ref>
The University of New Brunswick operates a wood chip burning furnace system to supply heat to the university, several industrial buildings, an apartment complex and a hospital.<ref name=":5" /> Usage of wood chips for heat is low in Quebec due to low hydroelectricity rates but a small town is using wood chips as an alternative to road salt for icy roads. EMC3 Technologies started producing wood chips coated with magnesium chloride in November 2017 for the town and has claimed it maintains traction in -30 degrees Celsius compared to regular road salt at -15 degrees Celsius.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/rosemere-wood-chips-1.4499146|title=Quebec town swaps out salt for eco-friendly wood chips on icy roads {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-04-12|language=en-US}}</ref> In Ontario, wood chip operations include a college in Brockville, a few secondary schools in Northern Ontario as well as a chip-fired boiler at the National Forestry Institute in Petawawa.<ref name=":5" /> In the late 1980’s, the Ontario provincial government in conjunction with the federal government subsidized building three co-generation plants next to sawmills. The first one was constructed in 1987 in Chapleau followed by a plant built in Cochrane in 1989 and the largest one in Kirkland Lake which was built in 1991.<ref name=":5" />
=== Europe === [[File:Forsthäcksler Hubertushof.jpg|right|thumb|Large wood chipper in Germany]] In several well wooded European countries (e.g. Austria, Finland, Germany, Sweden) woodchips are becoming an alternative fuel for family homes and larger buildings due to the abundant availability of woodchips, which result in low fuel costs. The European Union is promoting woodchips for energy production in the EU Forest action plan 2007–2011. The total long term potential of woodchips in the EU is estimated to be 913 million m<sup>3</sup>.<ref name="Yanez et al 2013" />
=== Japan === After a long period of negative scores, the demand of woodchips for paper manufacturing started increasing again. Starting in the last quarter of 2013, orders for printing paper and card board increased before the consumption tax increase then by weakening yen, import of papers like copy paper decreases and export of paper increases, which stimulate paper production in Japan. Softwood chip prices from the United States increased by 12% compared to October 2013 and softwood chip prices from Australia increased by 7%.<ref name="Fordaq">{{Cite news |work = ITTO |publisher = Fordaq S.A. |title = Good development for the Japanese wood chip market |url = http://www.fordaq.com/fordaq/news/Japan_wood_chip_market_37038.html |date = 15 May 2014 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140808045658/http://www.fordaq.com/fordaq/news/Japan_wood_chip_market_37038.html |archivedate = 8 August 2014 |df = }}</ref>
